backbone.name: Backbone
backbone.description: These blog posts will help you get up and running with Backbone.

getting-started.name: Getting Started
getting-started.description: The "Getting Started" section of the Backbone documentation gives a good overview of the different parts of Backbone.
getting-started.instructions: You only need to read the "Getting Started" section. You can stop once you get to Events. (If you want to skim through the F.A.Q, it has some interesting stuff, but don't worry if you don't understand everything right away.)

building-a-simple-backbone-app.name: Building a Simple Backbone App
building-a-simple-backbone-app.description: Explore the pieces of a simple app built with Backbone
building-a-simple-backbone-app.instructions: Try and get this code working on your local machine. If possible, pretend you're building it from the ground up. Add each piece of functionality, and get it working before you add the next. Heads up! This example will try to run a PHP file if you click the Order button. It's not required for this functionality to work, so you can safely ignore any errors or oddities you see if you submit the form on the page.

hello-backbone.name: Hello Backbone
hello-backbone.description: These five heavily commented code examples help you go from building simple apps to more complex ones.
hello-backbone.instructions: Get all of these code examples working on your computer. Don't only follow what the examples do. Take time to explore, and add your own features. Make the apps work how you want them to work. Note: The libraries that are referenced in the following tutorial use out of date versions. You can either use your own local instance of these libraries or use the following CDN's: underscore: https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/underscore.js/1.8.3/underscore-min.js jQuery: https://code.jquery.com/jquery-2.1.4.js Backbone: https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/backbone.js/1.2.1/backbone-min.js

addy-backbone-basics.name: Diving Deeper with Backbone
addy-backbone-basics.description: Addy Osmani's book is one of the best Backbone resources on the web. He'll help us explore Backbone's features and intricacies at a deeper level.
addy-backbone-basics.instructions: This is an incredible book, but it's also very detailed. This can be overwhelming. Read the entire Backbone Basics section until you get to the Summary (there's a Table of Contents at the top if it helps). You're not expected to memorize everything -- rather, you should notice all the things that Backbone can do, and come back to this resource later as a reference.

addy-todo-app.name: Building a Todo Application from Scratch
addy-todo-app.description: We explore how to build a app of a bit more complexity... and if you took JavaScript Design Patterns, it's an app you might recognize!
addy-todo-app.instructions: Build the app along with the book, but try to avoid blindly copying and pasting. Remember that every line of code does something, so make sure you try and figure out what that is before you type it in.

addy-library-app.name: Realtime Data with Firebase
addy-library-app.description: In this tutorial, the team at Firebase walks you through how to setup Firebase within a Backbone application to use as a persistent data store with realtime data-binding support!
addy-library-app.instructions: Follow along with this tutorial to create a to-do list application that, instead of using localStorage, uses Firebase as a persistent data store.

annotated-source-code.name: Backbone.js Annotated Source Code
annotated-source-code.description: This optional reading walks through the source code for Backbone itself!
annotated-source-code.instructions: This is a great resource for learning how Backbone actually works. Remember that even organizational libraries and frameworks are written in plain and understandable JavaScript.

Input-Controls.name: User Input Controls
Input-Controls.description: User Input Controls is just a fancy phrase for things in Android that you can see and interact with. Here you will find resources on how to use things like toggle buttons, radio buttons, spinners( drop downs) and more.

Toggle-Button.name: How do I use a Toggle button in Android?
Toggle-Button.description: ON/OFF. Those are the two states of a Toggle button. Follow the instructions in this blog to learn how to use a toggle button by creating a new android app from scratch

Edit-Text.name: How do I use Edit Text in an Android app?
Edit-Text.description: Edit Text is a box that allows a user to type text in your app. Read this blog and learn how to use Edit Text by creating a new app.

Arrays.name: How do I use Arrays (or lists) in Java?
Arrays.description: Arrays or Lists are used regularly in everyday life. Think of a To-Do list or a Menu at a restaurant. Here we will practice how to use Lists or Arrays in Java.
Arrays.instructions: Create a new HelloWorld app in Android. In the Java file (which is likely to be MainActivity.java), try out the Java code explained in this blog. We will use Arrays in many of the blogs that follow, so this is a great time to learn about them.

Autocomplete.name: How do I use autocomplete in my Android app?
Autocomplete.description: Have you ever noticed that you start typing in a box, and the app gives you suggestions on the thing you are typing. Here we will learn how to use autocomplete in you Android app.
Autocomplete.instructions: This tutorial uses lists or arrays in Java. If you are not familiar with them, check out the previous link in this series

Spinners.name: How do I use spinners (or dropdown lists) in my Android app?
Spinners.description: With Spinners you can allow users to easily pick a value from a list. Read this tutorial to learn how to use spinners in your app.

Radio-Button.name: How do I use radio buttons in my Android app?
Radio-Button.description: Follow this tutorial to learn how to use radio buttons in your Android app.
Radio-Button.instructions: Note that this tutorial will ask you to make a new Java class called RadioButtonSampleActivity.java. If you created a new Android project for this tutorial, then you can simply used the MainActivity.java class that was created for you by default.

Shortcuts.name: How do I use shortcuts to change the orientation of the emulator?
Shortcuts.description: Portrait and Landscape. Those are the two orientations available on the Android device (and the emulator). Read this stackoverflow page to learn about the different shortcuts available for the Android emulator.

Button-Click.name: How do I simulate a button click using code in my Android app?
Button-Click.description: So we know how to run a body of code when a user clicks a button in our app. How can we simulate that behavior without the user clicking anything on the app? Read this stackoverflow page to find out.

Menus.name: Menus
Menus.description: A menu is an interface which allows users to choose an item from several options. Here you will find resources on how to use menus like the Options Menu and the Pop-up Menu in Android.

Add-Import-Statements.name: How do I automatically add missing import statements in your code?
Add-Import-Statements.description: Now you are probably wondering that this article is not about Menus. That is correct. Although you will need the information listed in this article to be successful with the remaining tutorials in this series.
Add-Import-Statements.instructions: In this stackoverflow page you will discover techniques you can use to automatically add missing import statements to your code. We recommend that you open any old Android project, then delete an import statement and run the shortcut listed in this page to automatcially add the missing import statement.

Options-Menu.name: How do I create an options menu in my app? (video)
Options-Menu.description: An options menu allows a user to access options associated with an activity in Android. We recommend that you practice the instructions listed in this tutorial by creating a new app from scratch.

Popup-Menu.name: How do I use a popup menu in Android?
Popup-Menu.description: Read this article to learn about the popup menu in Android.
Popup-Menu.instructions: Note that while this stackoverflow page is great, it does not contain the code for import statements that are needed to run this code. The first article in this series has information on how to add missing import statements to your code.

Menu-Docs.name: What does Google have to say about Menus?
Menu-Docs.description: This is the official Google documentation on Menus. Skim this article. Don't worry if all of this does not make sense yet. Scan this page to find one interesting thing about Menus you did not know previously.

user-input-events.name: User Input Events
user-input-events.description: onClick is an example of a User Input Event. In this section, we will explore several tutorials on the ways a user can interact with an app. onLongClick and Drag and Drop are two such examples.

onlongclick-event.name: How do I use onLongClick in Android?
onlongclick-event.description: onLongClick, as the name suggests, is when a user presses and holds on to a button or item on your app. Create a new app to learn how onLongClick is used in Android.

drag-and-drop-simplified.name: How do I use drag and drop in Android?
drag-and-drop-simplified.description: This tutorial will give you a gentle introduction on how to implement the drag and drop feature in your Android app.
drag-and-drop-simplified.instructions: Now you might notice that @string/dragtext in the activity_main.xml file is undefined in this blog. Make sure to define it in the strings.xml

drawable-image.name: How do I display a background image in a TextView?
drawable-image.description: You are correct. This stackoverflow page will not teach you about a new user input event. Although, it will teach you how to display a background image on a view. And we will need this knowledge to fully understand the next tutorial in this series.

drag-and-drop.name: How do I use drag and drop in Android (with extra strength drag and drop)?
drag-and-drop.description: Read this article to learn how to use drag and drop in Android.

navigation.name: Navigation
navigation.description: Navigating around in an Android app is critical to every well designed app. In this section we will discuss several tutorials on this subject.

multiple-activities.name: How do I use multiple activities in my Android app?
multiple-activities.description: All of our apps thus far have contained only one activity (or screen). In this tutorial, we will learn how to use multiple activities in our app.

tabs.name: How do I use tabs in my Android app? (video)
tabs.description: Tabs are an important navigation tool in Android. Well, let's learn how to use them in this tutorial.

layouts.name: Layouts
layouts.description: Placing different views on the screen is critical to making any good app. ListView and GridView are two typical views that you will encounter in a lot of different apps. Here, we will learn about them.

listview.name: How do I create a simple list (like a To Do List) while using ListView?
listview.description: ListView is an incredibly popular layout. Many apps that want to lay things out like a list use this View. Let's learn more about it.
listview.instructions: Ok, three things to watch out for while using this tutorial. (I) When copying code from string.xml, you will find that the opening quotes throughout that file will not get copied correctly. You will have to remove and re-enter all opening quotes. (II) Inside string.xml, make sure that you keep the definition for action_settings. (III) In the Java code, refer to your layout name correctly i.e. R.layout.<insert your activity name>

best-practices.name: Best Practices
best-practices.description: Here we have collected a series of blogs that highlight best practices in Android that you should be aware of while making your apps.

accessibility.name: How do I make my apps more accessible?
accessibility.description: Adding Content Descriptors, which is a fancy word for labels, is one way to make your app more accessible to visually impaired users. Read through this article to learn about the things you can do to make your app more accessible.

color-schemes.name: Which color schemes are best to use in an Android app?
color-schemes.description: Colors are important. But you already knew that. Bookmark this tutorial to use a range of colors that look really good in an Android app.

more-color-schemes.name: How do I find out more about color schemes?
more-color-schemes.description: Had enough colors? We didn't think so. This tool will let you pick a few colors and show you what your app will look like before you even begin coding.

best-practices-from-google.name: What are some of the best practices I should think about while making my Android app?
best-practices-from-google.description: This blog will highlight important topics like managing multiple screen sizes, menu buttons and more. Spend some uninterrupted time reading through them and don't worry too much in case you don't understand everything listed here.

miscellaneous.name: Miscellaneous
miscellaneous.description: All important Android topics that could not find a home elsewhere are listed here.

play-sound.name: How do I play a sound in my Android app? (video)
play-sound.description: This video will walk you through the process of playing a sound through your app. In 30 minutes your app will look (and sound) much more amazing.

map.name: How do I add a map to my app?
map.description: Maps are cool. This is Google's official, updated documentation on how to use maps. It is a little tricky to understand, so ready carefully. Using a physical device (a phone) may make it easier to go through this tutorial.

share.name: How do I add the share button to my app? (video)
share.description: This video will walk you through how to share text from inside your app to other apps on your phone or emulator.
